Award.AwardTitle: Lattice Field Theory and Hadronic Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quarks carry a color charge and nuclear matter is formed from the binding of colored quarks mediated by gluons. Quantum Chromo-Dynamics (QCD) is the theory that describes the interaction of these color charges. Experiments have shown than quarks come in three colors but all nuclear matter is color neutral. Separation of nuclear matter into quarks and gluons needs very large energies similar to what was present in the early universe. Since solving QCD with three colors have proven to be very difficult and since qualitative properties do not depend on the number of colors, an attempt following 't Hooft is made to solve QCD for a very large number of colors. Research using lattice gauge theory has proven to be quite useful in extracting several physics results in the last six years. We will continue to make progress and focus on the phase of the theory that exists at high densities (like inside neutron stars) and high temperatures (close to the big-bang). Numerical computations will be used to study quark matter in this phase and we will attempt to make qualitative comparisons with current experiments in RHIC and CERN. Since QCD in the limit of large number of colors is closely related to recent developments in string theory we will also be able to make connections between field theory and string theory. We have already shown that quarks form a colorless condensate and we have also succeeded in computing the properties of the lightest colorless particle - the pion. We will attempt to compute the masses of other heavier colorless particles as part of this proposal. We will also attempt to study the effect of temperature thereby showing evidence for the formation of nuclear matter from a primordial soup of quarks and gluons.

The scientific methods involve analytical calculations and numerical computations. A graduate student at FIU working toward a Ph.D will learn quantum field theory and numerical techniques and will make significant contributions. Computer clusters will be used for numerical computations and the results obtained as part of this proposal will be presented at international conferences in nuclear and particle physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum Chromo-Dynamics (QCD) is a Color Gauge Theory that describes the interaction of Quarks (matter carrying color charges) with Gluons (mediator of the sub-nuclear force). Experiments have shown that the underlying color gauge group is SU(3) with quarks in the fundamental representation — There are eight gluons and three colors of quarks in nature. All nuclear matter is color neutral and are bound states of quarks and gluons. Theoretical physicists aiming to understand various phenomena associated with QCD have found it useful to consider a larger class of QCD like theories where one considers different color gauge groups; different representations of quarks; and different space-time dimensions. 

 

QCD is a confining theory at temperatures below the de-confining temperature which is about 264 MeV. The color flux contained by a color-current loop (Wilson loop) is proportional to the area and this leads to the string picture of QCD. Using the concept of continuum reduction in the limit of large number of colors, the string tension was computed in four dimensions and found to be close to (430 MeV)2. Even though the theory de-confines at high enough temperatures, chromo-magnetic Wilson loops still exhibit signs of confinement. A study of the chromo-magnetic string tension above the de-confinement temperature in three dimensional (two space and one time) QCD showed that it  grows with temperature in a linear form.

 

We proposed that one could use two dimensional (one space and one time) fermions coupled to three or four dimensional QCD as a probe of the physical transition from strongly interacting theory at large distances to a weakly interacting theory at short distances. We studied this problem in the limit of large number of colors. It was shown that as the size of the two dimensional space in which the fermions live was varied from small (weakly coupled theory) to large (strongly coupled theory), we could use chiral symmetry of the fermions as an order parameter and we found a critical size above which chiral symmetry was spontaneously broken. 

 

QCD at the classical level is scale invariant and it is broken at the quantum level resulting in the scale that separates the physics of strong interactions (the plethora of colorless bound states seen in experiments) from the physics of weak interactions (jet physics seen at high energy colliders). Whether scale invariance is broken or not at the quantum level in the larger class of QCD line theories depends on the number of colors; number and type of fermions. We investigated a certain sub-class of such theories: infinite number of colors and fermions in the adjoint representation. The motivation to investigate this sub-class is two fold: Reduction suggests that simpler looking matrix models can be used to study the underlying physics; the number of fermions can be tuned to continuously move from a theory that breaks scale invariance to one that does not. Analysis of such theories would help us understand the mechanism behind the natural scale that arises in QCD. Even though it does not seem possible to solve the matrix models using analytical techniques, we were able to show that numerical methods can yield useful results. We were able to place limits on the parameter space within which numerical methods can be used and we also developed numerical techniques appropriate for the study of these models. Preliminary results show that a detailed investigation is worth pursuing.
